column5: assessment method
A system is assessed yes (y) if it automatically assigns a persistent identifier to a research artefact.
column7: Publications have URLs with internal IDs. Bibtex Keys are also generated

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if, in addition to a possible unique identifier local to the system, it also supports the generation of a DOI for a research artefact.
column7: Nothing found in documentation about generating DOIs

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows the import of idenfiers of the research artefact, external to itself.
column7: When the meta data provider (publisher) provides the identifier, the identifier is imported.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a unique identifier for research artefacts that is dereferenceable to the artefact's location in the system.
column7: Inernal IDs form part of the URL to access the resource

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the metadata of the research artefact.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the content of the research artefact.
column7: If user upload full-text to post, the full-text content is indexed and searchable.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides advanced search features and, if so, justify by listing the features.
column7: Can constrain the search to specific categories of objects (publications, users, posts, etc.) and use complex queries based on common constructs (boolean operators, etc.)

column5: A system is assessed as providing language support (y) if its interface is available in more than one language.
column7: Available in English, German and Russian

column5: A system is assessed as providing protocols and APIs (y) if it makes available at least one protocol and/or API for access to research artefacts.
A system is assesssed yes (y) if it offers a convenient mechanism to perform a long term preservation beyond a simple database backup.
column7: No specific mechanism, but users can use backup-client (or every other client/script that can access the API) to backup their data.

column5: A system is assed high if the uptime is >= 99,9%, it is assessed medium if the uptime is between 99,9% and 99% and low if it is below 99% .
column7: Minimal downtime caused by issue in hosting network.

column5: A system is assessed open, if it makes research artefacts public by default. It is assessed as closed if it is primary designed for closed repositories. It is assessed on-request if it offers an on-request feature.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it employs a standardised and established format for providing the metadata.
column7: internal format does not follow standard, but standard formats are available for export

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the provision of data in common and standard file formats.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it assigns a persistent identifier (e.g. a stable URL) to the research artefacts.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows to customize, extend and limit the metadata schema/format.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the creation and publication of semantic links between different metadata and/or research artefacts.
column7: Publications can be linked between each other, e.g. cited publications, part of a collection

column3: Import and upload of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the import and upload of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the provision via a web interface.
column7: Possible to import through DOIs and ISBNs and other sources, through web frontend and extensions

column3: Export and download of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the export and download of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the download via a web interface.
column7: Can export metadata in multiple formats

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) it it supports the creation and maintenance of a customised submission process, including fine-grain access control and role assignment.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a built-in mechanism to make the metadata and data in other repositories (running the same system) available.
column7: No such function is mentioned, although a synchronisation mechanism is available with other services running. PUMA (installations at university libraries) also can submit their papers to a SWORD service.

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if it provides a highly usable and easy-to-understand mechanism to select a fitting licence for an artefact. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a customizable controlled list of licences.

A system is assessed high (h) if it provides an easy-to-understand and human-readable description of the terms of use. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a link to the applied licence.

A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows to access the actual content in a structured and machine-readable manner, if the data format supports it, for example, if a user can access the content of a CSV via an API.
A system is assessed high (h) if the documentation and support are of high quality and reachability.
A system is assessed according to this metrics based on usability testing carried out.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to notify users through mobile apps, email, or other mechanisms.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a way to customise and manage the publication/deposit workflow.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways to visualise the content of publications or datasets, at least for some formats.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to analyse the data in deposited research artefacts, including basic statistical analysis or more advanced methods.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables the publisher or administrator to change the aspect of pages on the system to reflect institutional affiliation.
column7: No such function is mentioned, although in local instalations the system's look can be changed by overriding some CSS.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways for users to create, name, and publish arbitrary sets of research artefacts.
column7: The group function makes it possible to create collections

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides pages for individual researchers, including at least the research artefacts they have authored/published.
column7: Users/authors have a page which can include details

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it gives the ability to users to provide simple positive feedback ("like") on research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to comment on individual research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides ways to share research artefacts with other users, on the system or other platforms (e.g. social media).
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to follow, and receive updates from, other users, research artefacts, collections, institutions, etc.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes discussion forums for users and/or for communication with/from the administrators.

For a proprietary, closed system, the assessement should be "closed" (c). For an open system, assessement is based on the frequency of activities in the development community (daily/weekly updates: high, monthly/quaterly updates: medium, less: low)
column7: Repository updated regularly, but not very active

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes an authentication mechanism for users.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a review functionality during submission by data stewards or other permitted organizational users.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes a functionality for writing reviews on specific research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (s) if it records usage statistics and (a) if it provides advanced research indicators like h-Index or AltMetrics.
Date at which the first available artefact was deposited on the platform.
column7: first bookmark in 2005, with 2006 being the official start of the project.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if the underlying system is open source.
column7: Open source repository available, although each component has its own licence

column5: A system is assessed as having high uptake (h) if it is used by a thousands of active users each month.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes automated backups in a constant time interval.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to get all data about one user.
column7: Data can be obtain through API, although it is unclear whether this includes all activitiy data.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to delete all data about one user.
column7: An account can be deleted. Pseudonymise data will remain in dumps created before the account was deleted.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows the user to opt-in, agreeing to single personal data management processes individually.
column7: The user has to accept the complete Terms of Use, she can not opt-in for specific parts.

column3: Portable and secure data exchange format
column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides all personal data in an open standard format (e.g. HTML, TXT, PDF).
column7: Data can be downloaded through API in JSON, XML, PDF

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes security tests for personal data.
